blocks.value: Early Life and Call to Religious Life

St. Anthony was born in Lisbon, Portugal, in 1195 and was baptized Fernando. At the age of 15, he entered the Canons Regular of St. Augustine. Later, inspired by the martyrdom of Franciscan missionaries in Morocco, Fernando joined the Franciscan Order and took the name Anthony. He set out to preach in Morocco but fell ill and had to return. On the return journey, his ship was blown off course and landed in Sicily, leading Anthony to Italy, where his true mission would unfold.

St. Anthony was an exceptional preacher and theologian. He was known throughout Italy and France for his powerful sermons, deep knowledge of Scripture, and ability to convert even the most hardened sinners. His preaching attracted large crowds, and his words led many back to the faith. He was also a great defender of the faith against heretics, particularly the Albigensians.

St. Anthony is known for many miracles, including preaching to the fish when people refused to listen, finding a miser's heart in his treasure chest, and helping a man reattach his severed foot. He is the patron saint of lost items because of the story of a young novice who stole his book of psalms. Anthony prayed, and the thief was moved to return the book. Since then, countless people have prayed to St. Anthony to help find lost items.

St. Anthony died on June 13, 1231, at the age of 35, in Padua, Italy, where he had been stationed. He was canonized less than a year later by Pope Gregory IX due to his holiness and the many miracles attributed to his intercession. In 1946, Pope Pius XII declared St. Anthony a Doctor of the Church, with the title "Evangelical Doctor," in recognition of his biblical preaching and his embodiment of the Gospel message.

St. Anthony is one of the most beloved and popular saints in the Catholic Church. He is the patron saint of lost items, lost people, and the poor. His feast day is celebrated on June 13th, and he is often invoked in prayer for help in finding lost things and for the grace of a holy death.
